ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a wide range of key concepts and theories important to the ER&M field, such as what it means to be in accompaniment, women of color feminism, queer of color critique, and decolonial methodology.

ER&M 300 offers a great synopsis on the past and present state of ethnic studies. Its one of the first (and only) classes where everyone is a major, and its also a great way to meet faculty in the department. At least in this iteration of the course, it was a great time to sharpen skills in analytic writing with the weekly reading responses.
This was a really thorough and expansive survey of comparative ethnic studies and I feel like really helped me develop my vocabulary and breadth of knowledge about ethnic studies as a large field.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: most readings were insightful; final project was meaningful and allowed for creativity; guest speakers were interesting

Weaknesses: class conversations were sometimes not engaging (could have benefited from small group conversations and more interactive activities); weekly 1-2 page single spaced response papers was a lot on top of the already dense/long readings

Truly fantastic course! The highlight was definitely the self-directed final project. There was a lot of flexibility in how we could do it, and I think it was nice to have an assignment not strictly centered on something academic. It was also great to meet your peers in the major. Professor Vora was also kind and knowledgeable; she definitely brought a fresh perspective to the readings.

The readings gave us such a broad range and were also really interesting. Class discussions were super fruitful and well organized. I think slightly shorter reading responses would make the courseload more manageable because it was a bit difficult to keep up since readings tended to be heavy too.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend ER&M 200 as a more basic, foundational course for non-ER&M majors because this course might be more advanced.
Its required for the major, so recommendation may be a bit moot. If Professor Vora ever teaches it again, however, I absolutely recommend taking it with her!

I would! Aside from it being required for ER&M majors, it was a really strong synthesis of a lot of the themes present in other ER&M and related courses, helping us build a more cohesive understanding of the field.
